utterances: Yeah, who are you?
Who do you support?
And I think I speak for all three of us here, we really have seen a greater appreciation for the listeners in looking at these questions.
There are number of - first of all, there's a large number of questions.
They're smart.
They're sharp.
It's clear that people have been paying attention - close attention to the issues.
And the questions are quite impressive.
Let's get a listener question here.
This is Bryan(ph).
Bryan with us from Detroit in Michigan.
Yeah, hi.
Thanks for taking my call.
I'm a big fan of your show.
Sure.
Thank you.
This is a question I would love to ask both the Democratic and Republican candidates, but this is about the Democrats, particularly Hillary Clinton but I guess all of them.

One of things that was really apparent when George Bush came into power is he basically hired and/or appointed all of the same cronies that were in his dad's administration and basically, all the Republican administrations going back for several decades.
In reality, you married my daughter and that was it.
But if anybody else were in my shoes, they could have been completely shut out and not had anything.
So, I understand how blessed I am to be a part of your family.
I'm Alex Chadwick, and DAY TO DAY has more just ahead.

I guess I want to know, you know, who are they going to hire, who's - is Hillary going to basically surround herself by a bunch of people who've been on the inside for the past 10 to 20 years and it's going to be more the same?
Or who is she going to appoint to be, you know, in her advisory council, if you will.

I just think that's a big part of the problem that we've had for the past several decades is that continuity of corruption and I guess I want to know what they're going to - how they are going to answer that.
Steve?
Can't give you a full answer on who she's going to appoint, but I can tell you, Bryan, that this is a question that will be addressed on NPR.
Can't say whether it'll be in the debate but our own political correspondent - national political correspondent Mara Liasson is looking at the question of a Clinton dynasty and what that means.
And I believe she'll be burrowing other news developments, reporting that on NPR's MORNING EDITION tomorrow.
And we should…
Well, that's great.
I mean, I'd like to hear the other candidates answer that, too.
But obviously, for, you know, Hillary Clinton, it's particularly pertinent.
You know, I care about the issues.

I care about their programmatic solutions, but all of that can change as soon as they're elected and ultimately, it comes down to who are they surrounding themselves with and what are they trying to get done.
Robert?
I would just add, Bryan, that, you know, another way of saying, I'm going to bring in all the same old tired hacks who used to be in the administration.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Another way of saying this, I'm going to bring people who have experienced at actually making policy in Washington.
So it's a question where you can see the glass either half full or half empty the way you look at it.
It's also - Michele, go ahead.
I was just going to say that Bryan's question also goes to something that I think many of us are hearing on the ground here.
On one side, voters are talking about the dynastic nature of Hillary Clinton's candidacy, the sort of hopscotch Bush-Clinton Bush-Clinton nature, and whether this would be sort of back to the future.

On the other hand, if you listen to Barack Obama and look at the ads that he's running on television, it's all about change, that, you know, you're going to see sort of a new face and a new administration, so he's really keen in something we hear here.
Isn't this typically, though, an area, Bryan, don't you think, that is has left two presidents elect actually being able to offer jobs to people and saying, and you're actually be offered this job?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I think that's true.

But I mean, again, just from the, you know, man-on-the-street-voter perspective, you know, we've been through this before, where a candidate, you know, promises to do X, Y and Z and says, you know, these issues are most important to them and they surround themselves with people who then go, you know, take them off into a different direction, whether the candidate-elect, you know, that's going willingly or not, you know, sort of depends on the personality, you know.
And often, you know, you just kind of sit back and say, okay, here we go again.
I'm going to disengage.
Okay.
Thanks very much for the call, Bryan.
Let's turn now to Kristy(ph).
And if I'm pushing the buttons correctly, Kristy joins us from Boise, Idaho.
Hi.
How you all doing today?
Very well, thanks.
Hi, Kristy.
Good.
My question is about the housing crisis that we're in now.
My family is in general contracting.
And we've been seriously affected by the housing crisis right now.
Like we have five houses that are just sitting there not selling at all.

And my question for the candidates would be how are they going to address this situation not only to those that have defaulted on their loans but those that have made their livelihood in this industry that are now floundering and facing bankruptcy?
Housing - the crisis has blown up rather late in this campaign as it continues to get deeper and deeper.
Is that a subject that you - well, you're not going to tell us exactly what you're doing, but this certainly is a legitimate issue?
Steve?
Oh, Kristy's been legitimate, if anything, when she says…
That's Robert, yeah.
I'm sorry.
No please, go ahead.
No, no. I mean, it's a very serious issue.
I don't know if we'll get to it tomorrow.
Or and if I did, I wouldn't tell you, Neal.
But obviously, it's a - this is a very serious issue.
You can read about it in the financial papers as the liquidity crisis.
But if you're in Kristy's situation or, for that matter, if you're about to go delinquent on your mortgage, your language worth is a lot less delicate than that.
This is a terrible situation and no one seems to know just what the depth of the problem is at this point.
Can I do a reporting here, Kristy?
Where are you?
(Unintelligible) this is our livelihood as well.
And I think that we've been focusing on the people that have entered into these loans.
And so the people that actually make their living in this industry that is going absolutely nowhere right now.
And…
Where are the five houses?
These are at Boise…
She's calling us…
…Idaho.
Boyce, Idaho.
And they can't be sold at any price?
We've lowered the price so far that it's to the point where - at this point, we're going to cover our costs and the cost of paying the loan monthly.
So we have to maintain these houses outside of foreclosure.
We will be making almost zero profit out of it.
And that's our, you know, our yearly income, you know, that's one-fifth of our yearly income, just one home.
So five homes, I mean, that's it.
That's what we have.
One other question, again, in the construction industry.
Immigrant workers have often played a very large role.
Is that your case there in Boise?
Well, I want you to know that I'm very proud of you.
I consider you mine because Donna considered you hers, and I wouldn't have it any other way.
Oh, absolutely.
It's a huge part and, you know, we do our best to make sure that everybody - all of our subcontractors are doing everything legitimately.
But at the same time, you know, we've got so many costs on top of us that we have to go for those that, you know, give us the lowest price bids for the work that they can do.
And oftentimes, there are people that are hiring people that are not necessarily working here legally.
Okay.
And so we…
It's like a conundrum.
We could probably throw a health coverage in there, too, which is also a problem.
But we'll move on.
Thanks very much for the call, Kristy, and good luck selling those houses.
Thank you and you all have a great day.
Our guests currently are Steve Inskeep, Michele Norris and Robert Siegel, the hosts of ALL THINGS CONSIDERED and MORNING EDITION, respectively.
They're going to the moderators of a debate of Democratic presidential candidates tomorrow brought to you by NPR News and Iowa Public Radio.
